awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: RUI: Low Correlation and Highly Nonlinear Structures for Communications and Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Many communications and remote sensing systems require modulation protocols that are described by digital sequences, which may be regarded as words composed of symbols from a prescribed alphabet, such as the binary alphabet with symbols 0 and 1. The efficiency of the system will often depend on producing sequences that are as uncorrelated as possible: they should not resemble shifted (time-delayed) versions of each other, nor even of themselves. Lack of resemblance between a sequence and shifted versions of itself aids in synchronization and timing, which is useful in radar and sonar. Lack of resemblance between two different sequences (no matter how they are shifted) prevents confusion between different users in communications networks. Random sequences are not ideal for these applications, as even random sequences are expected to have occasional repetitions. It is more advantageous to use pseudorandom sequences that avoid repetition to a greater degree than random sequences do. These pseudorandom sequences and related mathematical structures, such as Boolean functions, are also significant in other information-theoretic problems, such as in cryptography, where one seeks to design permutations that have a simple underlying mathematical form (to ease encryption and decryption) but avoid resembling easily detectable patterns (to resist cryptanalysis). Pseudorandom sequences find further applications in error-correcting codes, antenna arrays, scientific instrumentation, and acoustic design, and thus science and technology benefit both from the analysis of known digital sequences and the discovery of new ones.

The goal of this project is to create and investigate digital sequences and related mathematical structures with good correlation properties. This project considers both periodic and aperiodic forms of correlation, as both are important in applications. In periodic correlation, the shifting of the sequences is cyclic, and the maximum length linear feedback shift register sequences (m-sequences) are a common building block in the design of digital sequences with low periodic correlation. Finding pairs of m-sequences with low mutual correlation is equivalent to finding highly nonlinear permutations of finite fields, which can be used to make cryptosystems resilient to linear cryptanalysis. This project will investigate m-sequence pairs with exceptional correlation properties, which translate into exceptional nonlinearity properties of the corresponding permutations. Extremal properties, such as exceptionally high nonlinearity or exceptionally few correlation values, are sought out, and this project will investigate bounds and limitations on these extremes using tools from abstract algebra, combinatorics, and number theory, as well as empirical computational explorations. In aperiodic correlation, the shifting of sequences is a non-cyclic translation, and various families of sequences whose correlation properties make them superior to random sequences are known, but their analysis has been difficult and many open questions remain. This project will analyze the performance of these sequences both empirically and theoretically, and will seek new families of sequences with good correlation properties

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was the creation and analysis of structures that are useful in reliable communications and sensing technologies.  These include sequences with low correlation, which are used to modulate signals used in ranging and communications.  They also include functions with high nonlinearity that are essential to the creation of cryptographic protocols.  An important aspect of this project was to advance the state of knowledge in collaborations with students, thus allowing them to experience research that will prepare and encourage them to consider becoming researchers in mathematics, science, and engineering.

Sequences of binary digits are used to modulate signals in digital communications and remote sensing.  In a communications network with many users or a sensing system with many transmitters, one needs families of many sequences (for the many transmissions) that are as uncorrelated as possible in the sense that (1) no sequence should resemble a time delayed version of itself, and (2) no sequence should resemble any other sequence in the family, nor any time delayed version of any other sequence in the family.  The first aspect, called low autocorrelation, is important for synchronization and determining range.  The second aspect, called low crosscorrelation, prevents different transmitters from being confused.

This project examined the Rudin-Shapiro-like sequences, many of which have low autocorrelation.  The merit factor is a measure that averages the squared values of all the correlations between a sequence and time delayed versions of itself to give an overall measure of how low the autocorrelation is.  We discovered the precise design criterion that is necessary and sufficient to produce families of Rudin-Shapiro-like sequences whose limiting merit factor is as high as possible (making the sum of squares of the autocorrelations as low as possible).

The merit factor gives an average-case estimate of how low the autocorrelation is.  Another important measure is the peak sidelobe level, which is a worst-case measure rather than an average one: it rates the sequence on the highest magnitude of the correlations it has with time delayed versions of itself, so a low peak sidelobe level is desirable.  We proved bounds on the peak sidelobe level of a large family of sequences called the Golay-Rudin-Shapiro sequences, including very precise bounds on the peak sidelobe level of the famous Rudin-Shapiro sequences.

This project also studied crosscorrelation, which has its own merit factor (mean-squared) measures and peak (worst-case) measures.  Golay-Rudin-Shapiro sequences are constructed in pairs that have low mutual crosscorrelation, and the study mentioned in the previous paragraph also proved bounds on their peak crosscorrelation.  The Golay-Rudin-Shapiro sequence pairs belong to a larger class of sequence pairs called Golay complementary pairs, which have lowest possible combined mean-square autocorrelation and crosscorrelation among all sequence pairs.  We determined the limiting autocorrelation and crosscorrelation merit factors for large families of Golay complementary pairs.

This project did not just study single sequences and pairs of sequences.  We also devised a procedure for making families of many sequences with low correlation (according to both mean-square and worst-case measures) from constructions involving mathematical objects called multiplicative characters of finite fields.  We determined the precise criteria needed to obtain families whose worst-case performance is good.  We then provided the theoretical tools for determining the mean-square measures of correlation for such families, and obtained some constructions with exceptionally good properties.

The sequences mentioned up to this point have been non-repeating, or aperiodic, sequences.  There are also periodic sequences, and their correlation properties are also important in information theory.  Furthermore, knowing the crosscorrelation performance of certain periodic sequences (called m-sequences) is equivalent to knowing about the nonlinearity of permutations of finite fields of interest to cryptographers.  The Walsh transform gives a measure of how nonlinear a function is, and cryptographers seek highly nonlinear functions to foil cryptanalysis.  In 1972, Yoji Niho posed a difficult conjecture about the crosscorrelation of a certain infinite family of m-sequences, or equivalently, about the Walsh transform of an infinite family of permutations.  This problem had stood unsolved for almost fifty years, but we finally solved it by devising a new method of analysis.

The work of this project was accomplished with the help of many collaborators, both from the home institution (California State University, Northridge) and from other institutions.  A large number of the collaborators are students, many of whom have graduated from California State University, Northridge and gone on to further studies or jobs in teaching and industry.
